name: Wells-fargo-data-competition
body:
## Well Fargo Data Analytics Competition
The Project was created as a part of competition organized by Wells Fargo. The data set consisted of 220,337 posts taken from both FaceBook and Twitter with mediatype specified. The posts contained discussions around four major banks called BankA, BankB, BankC and BankD. The only guideline for competitors was that the analysis needed to be innovative and interesting. 

## Our team
The data analysis was a group effort. Our team consisted of 3 students:
* @mikaelarae - Major: Sociology minoring in Data Science;
* @tiffanirgriffith - Major: Math and undegrad in Marine Biology;

## Strategy
Our group was interested in finding what people say about their experience with given banks when it came to international transactions, travelling and being abroad.

The first step we took was to subset the dateframe into separate dataframes by the bank name and the presense of the following words:
"abroad" and "foreign".

```R
bankA.idx = which(sapply(df$FullText,function(x) grepl("BankA",x)))
bankB.idx = which(sapply(df$FullText,function(x) grepl("BankB",x)))
bankC.idx = which(sapply(df$FullText,function(x) grepl("BankC",x)))
bankD.idx = which(sapply(df$FullText,function(x) grepl("BankD",x)))

df.bankA=df[bankA.idx,]
df.bankA
abroad.idx=which(sapply(df.bankA$FullText,function(x) grepl("abroad",x)))
abroad.idx

foreign.idx=which(sapply(df.banka$FullText,function(x) grepl("foreign",x)))
foreign.idx

df.final1=df.banka[abroad.idx,]
df.final2=df.banka[foreign.idx,]
...
```

Once the dataset was devided into 4 subsets, we then used a modified sentiment analysis. The list of negative words taken from http://www.cs.uic.edu/~liub/FBS/sentiment-analysis.html*

> *Minqing Hu and Bing Liu. "Mining and Summarizing Customer Reviews." 
> Proceedings of the ACM SIGKDD International Conference on Knowledge 
> Discovery and Data Mining (KDD-2004), Aug 22-25, 2004, Seattle, 
> Washington, USA. 

Besides the list of negative words provided from this source, we added a list of words with negative connotation specifically imposed by bank customers. For example:

```
Charge
Carged
Charging
....
Overdraft
Overdrafted
Overdrafting
...
Widthdraw
Widthdrawal
Widthdrew
...
```

The following graphs reflect the very negative/positive score per bank as a result of sentiment analysis:

![Negatibe BankA](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-4HiKd7BmSnI/VmCSWySLGxI/AAAAAAAAA5M/oS2nBB8JaNk/s683-Ic42/Neg%252528Bank_A%252529.png)


![Negative Bank B](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-BDKj-rUQuOo/VmCSWz3ZHjI/AAAAAAAAA5o/gjK_bg0yPLU/s683-Ic42/Neg%252528Bank_B%252529.png)


![Negative Bank C](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-mmO8xLbdcm4/VmCSXNac26I/AAAAAAAAA5Y/st4LuxxFHO0/s683-Ic42/Neg%252528Bank_C%252529.png)


![Negative Bank D](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-M5njmsU5D8U/VmCSXHpJZII/AAAAAAAAA5k/pb-T7tIpI0s/s712-Ic42/Neg%252528Bank_D%252529.png)


![Positive Bank A](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-Kk1RYvBJKNg/VmCSXR8i7_I/AAAAAAAAA5U/47JGo6Bl_SA/s712-Ic42/Pos%252528Bank_A%252529.png)


![Posite Bank B](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-EXndilXNOZ0/VmCSXZXZztI/AAAAAAAAA5Q/YGTAU7Z1zjg/s712-Ic42/Pos%252528Bank_B%252529.png)


![Positive Bank B](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-ndFHffH1fF4/VmCSXZTIV9I/AAAAAAAAA5c/4KqIMLHdoyQ/s712-Ic42/Pos%252528Bank_C%252529.png)


![Positive Back D](https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-MADTYAzQ8MA/VmCSXmiWBiI/AAAAAAAAA5g/5cziQcECgcc/s712-Ic42/Pos%252528Bank_D%252529.png)


As shown in the graphs, Bank C had the highest Negative score, which means its customers were more dissappointed with internatioinal transactions than the customers of other banks. Bank A got the highest poitive score, which means that customers of Bank A were more satisfied with their international experience than others. However, when comparing Bank A's positive (0.6) and negative (0.68) scores, they are nearly equal. Thus, when considering results of sentiment score, it makes more sense to make cunclusions based on positive/negative ratio. In case of Bank A it equals to 0.88 (with 1 representing 50%/50% relationships).

When further investigating scores, in case of all 4 banks, posts tend to contain more negative lexicon than positive. The numbers are distributed as follows:

```
**Bank A: **
Total negative score: 0.68
Total positive score: 0.6
Positive/Negative ratio: 0.88

**Bank B: **
Total negative score: 0.62
Total positive score: 0.45
Positive/Negative ratio: 0.73

**Bank C: **
Total negative score: 0.805
Total positive score: 0.425
Positive/Negative ratio: 0.53

**Bank D: **
Total negative score: 0.57
Total positive score: 0.34
Positive/Negative ratio: 0.60
```

Bank B has the biggest negative ratio, versus Bank D having the biggest positive one. This concludes, that according to the sentiment analysis, customers of Bank B were more dissapointed with their bank's performance than customers of other banks, and customers of Bank D were more satisfied with their bank than customers of other banks.

## Additional exploration

It would also be helpful to have a look at the most frequently used words in all the 4 subsets.
To do that we will need to make sure the following packages are installed: "SnowballCC", "RColorBrewer", "tm", "ggplot2", "wordcloud","cluster", "igraph", "fpc", "biclust":

```R
packages_to_install <- c("SnowballCC", "RColorBrewer", "tm", "ggplot2", "wordcloud","cluster", "igraph", "fpc", "biclust")   
install.packages(Needed, dependencies=TRUE)

install.packages("Rcampdf", repos = "http://datacube.wu.ac.at/", type = "source")    

library(tm)
library(SnowballC)   
```

The next step is to create the Corpus:

```R
corpus <- Corpus(VectorSource(df.banka$FullText))
corpus
```
and to clean it up:convert to lower case, remove numbers, remove the most common words (like "the") that don't need to be counted, remove punctuation, strip the space, trim, and, finally, cooonvert it to a plain text document:

```R
clean_corpus <- tm_map(corpus, tolower)
clean_corpus <- tm_map(clean_corpus, removeNumbers)
clean_corpus <- tm_map(clean_corpus, removeWords, stopwords('english'))
clean_corpus <- tm_map(clean_corpus, removePunctuation)
clean_corpus <- tm_map(clean_corpus, stripWhitespace)
clean_corpus <- tm_map(clean_corpus, trim)
clean_corpus <- tm_map(clean_corpus, PlainTextDocument)
```
And finally, to be able to run the word frequencies, it is necessary to create the DocumentTermMatrix:

```R
dtm <- DocumentTermMatrix(clean_corpus)
``` 
Given that the data set is quite big, the minimum term frequency was set as 800 for each bank. Using the df.banka data set, the findFreqTerms() gives the following results for each bank:

### Bank A
```R
 [1] "account"       "anyone"        "arena"         "bank"          "banka"         "bankac"        "bankb"        
 [8] "bankd"         "banker"        "banking"       "banks"         "bit"           "business"      "call"         
[15] "can"           "cant"          "card"          "cash"          "center"        "check"         "come"         
[22] "company"       "credit"        "customer"      "day"           "deposit"       "dlvr"          "dont"         
[29] "even"          "ever"          "family"        "first"         "get"           "give"          "going"        
[36] "good"          "got"           "great"         "help"          "home"          "internet"      "job"          
[43] "just"          "know"          "last"          "let"           "like"          "loan"          "love"         
[50] "make"          "money"         "mortgage"      "much"          "name"          "nameresp"      "need"         
[57] "never"         "new"           "now"           "one"           "open"          "pay"           "people"       
[64] "phone"         "photo"         "please"        "rebanke"       "rettwit"       "right"         "said"         
[71] "see"           "service"       "still"         "store"         "support"       "take"          "team"         
[78] "thank"         "thanks"        "tickets"       "time"          "today"         "twithndl"      "twithndlbanka"
[85] "use"           "want"          "way"           "well"          "will"          "work"          "year"         
[92] "years"    
``` 

### Bank B
```R
 [1] "account"           "anyone"            "atm"               "bank"              "banka"            
 [6] "bankb"             "bankc"             "bankd"             "banke"             "banking"          
[11] "banks"             "bit"               "business"          "buy"               "call"             
[16] "can"               "cant"              "card"              "cash"              "check"            
[21] "chicago"           "credit"            "customer"          "day"               "debit"            
[26] "dont"              "even"              "feedbankb"         "financial"         "first"            
[31] "fraud"             "get"               "getting"           "give"              "going"            
[36] "good"              "got"               "great"             "help"              "home"             
[41] "ift"               "internet"          "just"              "know"              "last"             
[46] "let"               "like"              "make"              "marathon"          "money"            
[51] "mortgage"          "name"              "nameresp"          "need"              "never"            
[56] "new"               "now"               "number"            "one"               "pay"              
[61] "people"            "phone"             "please"            "rebanke"           "rettwit"          
[66] "right"             "said"              "see"               "service"           "settlement"       
[71] "share"             "stadium"           "still"             "take"              "team"             
[76] "thank"             "thanks"            "time"              "today"             "twithndl"         
[81] "twithndlbanka"     "twithndlbankb"     "twithndlbankbhelp" "use"               "want"             
[86] "way"               "well"              "will"              "work"              "years" 
```

### Bank C
```R
 [1] "account"       "bank"          "bankb"         "bankc"         "bankd"         "bit"           "business"     
 [8] "buy"           "can"           "card"          "credit"        "dlvr"          "get"           "ift"          
[15] "internet"      "just"          "money"         "name"          "new"           "now"           "pay"          
[22] "price"         "rating"        "rettwit"       "twithndl"      "twithndlbankc" "will"  
```


### Bank D
```R
 [1] "account"       "advisers"      "apply"         "asset"         "bank"          "banka"         "bankb"        
 [8] "bankc"         "bankd"         "bankds"        "banking"       "banks"         "bit"           "business"     
[15] "can"           "card"          "cash"          "check"         "company"       "credit"        "data"         
[22] "day"           "dont"          "financial"     "full"          "get"           "good"          "got"          
[29] "grants"        "group"         "help"          "https"         "ift"           "internet"      "just"         
[36] "know"          "learn"         "like"          "main"          "make"          "management"    "managers"     
[43] "million"       "mission"       "money"         "name"          "need"          "neutral"       "new"          
[50] "news"          "now"           "one"           "overweight"    "people"        "price"         "program"      
[57] "rating"        "rettwit"       "see"           "small"         "stockport"     "street"        "swing"        
[64] "target"        "time"          "today"         "transfer"      "twithndl"      "twithndlbankd" "vote"         
[71] "wealth"        "will"          "year" 
```
Now, having the results of the most frequent words, we can compare them to the previous analysis and search for positive and negative connatations. As the negative/positive ratio showed, bank B had the worst negative score. In addition to that, among the most frequent words, there are words like: "fraud" and "never". 

Similarly, the list of the most frequent words for bank D, with the best positive score, conatins: "advisers", "asset", "wealth".

Further analysis could bring more conclusions.
